results.title: Screen magazine. No. 8
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This is the United Nations”
Cinemagazine items: 1. UN at work on world wide system of road signs - An amusing allegory with cartoons by Steinburg. Explains how the two different systems used in Europe and America make it difficult for a travelling motorist to find their way outside their own country. 2. Eritrea federated to Ethiopia - Explains how United Nations investigated political problems posed by Eritrea, a former Italian colony on the Red Sea. The population was divided in race and religion; the land poor; political opinions strongly divided; some sought independence; some wanted union with Ethiopia. After the report by a UN Commission, the General Assembly decided to federate the country to Ethiopia within two years.

results.title: Screen magazine. No. 16
results.creator_credit: United Nations. Dept. of Public Information and United Nations. Film Board
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This is the United Nations”
The people of Afghanistan have followed a way of life that has changed very little in the past thousand years. In 1950 the Afghanistan Government, which has been making efforts to develop and improve the country, called upon the U.N. to help by providing technical assistance. This film describes how new knowledge and techniques have been introduce into industry and agriculture, resulting in increasing output and development of resources.

results.title: Screen Magazine. No. 13. Help for Pakistan
results.creator_credit: United Nations. Dept. of Public Information
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This is the United Nations”.
When Pakistan became an independent country in 1947, help was need by the United Nations to develop the land more extensively and establish industries. It was the people themselves who first received help from the UN. As a result of the Technical Assistance Schemes of the United Nations, Pakistanis are making more of the things they once imported, thus achieving a balance between agriculture and industry.

results.title: Screen magazine. No. 12
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “This is the United Nations”.
Cinemagazine items: 1. Fundamental education - Mexico has developed a Fundamental Education Program which has resulted in the raising of living standards in the country and the establishment of a Training Centre for representatives from other Latin-American nations. 2. United nations stamps - On 24th October 1951, the United Nations issued its first stamp. This film shows the designing and printing of the stamps and points out their significance as they pass freely over all frontiers.

results.title: Screen magazine. No. 11
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This is the United Nations”
Cinemagazine items: 1. Social welfare seminar at work - Shows a seminar on social welfare convened in Cairo at the request of the Egyptian Government. Illustrates the work of the UN Technical Assistance Administration. 2. Mexico electrification - Shows how the World Bank loan to Mexico has extended electrical power in that country. Explains how the increase in power affects the social and cultural life of Mexico.

results.title: Screen magazine. No. 10
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This is the United Nations”.
Cinemagazine items: 1. Guatemala tells a new story - The United Nations is at work in this Central American country, bringing a new way of life to the inhabitants, who struggle to exist in a barren and unfertile land. 2. Palestine refugees - As a result of political upheaval in the Near East, nearly a million Arab refugees have fled to the deserts of Palestine. The United Nations has set up a Relief and Works Agency to assist these refugees.

results.title: Screen magazine. No. 07
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This is the United Nations”.
Cinemagazine items: 1. The International Court of Justice - This Court, the highest of all tribunals, is the principal judicial organ of the United Nations. It holds its sessions in the Peace Palace at the Hague, Holland and consists of fifteen independent judges, elected regardless of nationality. 2. The Republic of Indonesia - When the Japanese were driven out of the Dutch colony of Indonesia at the end of World War II the national leaders declared the country a republic. However negotiations with the Dutch resulted in violence. When peace was finally established by United Nations action, it was agreed that Indonesia become a sovereign state linked to the Netherlands in a union based on free will with equal rights.

results.title: Screen magazine. No. 06
results.creator_credit: Leo Herwood and United Nations. Film Board
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This is the United Nations”.
Cinemagazine items: 1. London centre checks influenza - By swift recognition of the type and strain of virus causing influenza, the World Health Organisation centre at London helps to check epidemics. 2. UN laboratory aids fight on opium smuggling - In New York the UN narcotic Division has set up a laboratory which identifies the source of any opium seized, thus assisting authorities to trace smugglers.

results.title: Screen magazine. No. 05
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This is the United Nations”.
Cinemagazine items: 1. Indian students perform for UN club - Members of the United Nations Secretariat regularly learn about the cultures of many nations. The songs and dances of India are presented and explained. 2. UN votes independence for Libya by 1952 - After centuries of living under conquerors, Libya was liberated by the Allies in 1943. United Nations voted in 1949 that Libya should become an independent and sovereign state by 1952. A UN Commission is helping Libya to work out her transition from colonial status to independence.
